key_points: Republicans in the Senate blocked a bill to establish an independent commission to investigate the January 6 Capitol riot.
The bill failed a key procedural vote with 54 votes in favor and 35 against, missing the required 60 votes.
Senate Democratic Leader Chuck Schumer accused Republicans of defending the 'Big Lie' and fearing political repercussions from Donald Trump.
Republicans, including Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell, argued the commission would politically damage their party and was unnecessary.
The proposed commission aimed to probe the security and intelligence failures on January 6 and Trump's role in inciting the riot.
The commission would have been bipartisan, with equal representation from Republicans and Democrats.
35 House Republicans supported the legislation, but it lacked enough Republican support in the Senate.
Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene warned Republicans the commission would be used to smear Trump supporters.
Democrats and some moderate Republicans voiced frustration over the opposition, citing the need for accountability.
With the Senate's rejection, there are calls for a select congressional committee to investigate the January 6 breach.
spokespersons: Gladys Sicknick (Mother of deceased Capitol Police officer Brian Sicknick)
